title: awesome recipe!
text:
I stumbled across your hack as I was looking for standing desk ideas, and I gave it a try. I'm incredibly pleased with the results!! I even wrote a blog post about it: http://mycrankygut.com/2012/09/10/its-not-always-about-cranky-guts-and-fancy-diets/ One thing you didn't mention, and I thought I should point out... when securing the nut on the middle-rear tabletop bracket, BE VERY CAREFUL NOT TO OVERTIGHTEN!! author: Charley (Guest)
title: Dunn & Dunn!
text:
Hi. Just letting you know I built a desk using your design. Exactly the same, just using one Expedit, and a shorter Vika Amon top. So, half as wide, in other words.

The only difference was, for the front Capita brackets I kept the round discs on top of the brackets to make the desk flat back to front. I hacksawed the bolts down and drilled two pilot holes in the front underside of the desk, and the cut bolts popped into those. You gotta be careful with those Vika Amon tops, as they are hollow in the middle.

BTW, I didn't use epoxy, but I did squeeze some "no more nails" down the screw holes to give the screws some better purchase. Both the Expedit and the Vita Amon tops are made of a composite wood material which screws can turn to sawdust over time. Especially if you over tighten them! I used a manual screwdriver for the final turns, just to make sure the drill didn't gouge the wood.

Thanks again for your design. The cost of the project for me was $200 (Australian)

text:

I already had the Expedit bookcase, so this ran about $150 total.  The 6" legs are correct for me at 6'2", although I spaced 4 legs evenly on each long end of the bookcase in my design.  We also shimmed the front braces to make the table level.

I really appreciate your putting this guide together; do you take PayPal/Google Checkout donations?

author: Guest (Guest)
title: Epoxy
text: I don't know if epoxy is needed. But at least for the bottom legs I think it's a good idea. From my experience screws in particule bard or very weak if you move them laterally (like moving the desk). On the other hand adhesives like epoxy are very good at that. So i figure screws + epoxy should help. Note that Expedit material is not too bad compare to some other Ikea stuff.
